park.name: Big Bend National Park
park.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.altText: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.altText: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: Santa Elena Canyon

images.altText: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.caption: Big Bend is a place of expansive views

images.caption: The Rio Grande serves as the park's southern boundary

images.caption: Big Bend is home to over 450 species of birds!

images.altText: Century Plant Agave
images.caption: Century Plants bloom only once in their long lives.

images.caption: Cenizo, or Big Bend Silverleaf blossoms after summer rains.

images.title: Blooming Ocotillo

images.caption: When ocotillo bloom, they transform the desert

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.altText: Balanced Rock
images.caption: The balanced rock is a popular day hiking destination.

images.title: Chisos Mountains

images.caption: The Chisos Mountains rise above the desert

images.title: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.altText: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: Hiking the Lost Mine Trail affords many amazing views.

eatery.description: The Colorado dining scene has come a long way since the Buckhorn Exchange opened. There's practically a brewery and a buzzed-about restaurant on every street corner in Denver these days. But the Buckhorn Exchange is a glimpse into what Colorado restaurants used to be famous for -- giant portions of steak that will feed you, your friends, and your friends' friends. Beyond the steak, there's also the opportunity to eat practically every animal that was on Noah's ark. And eating here puts you in good company, as Teddy Roosevelt and Eisenhower both dined here.

attraction.name: Snake World
attraction.description: The next time you’re in Arkansas, be sure to stop by Snake World! Owner Dale Ertel claims that the tourist attraction houses over 70 snakes, which is even more than the Little Rock Zoo. The reviews on Trip Advisor are all glowing, and warn visitors not to be dissuaded by Snake World’s sketchy exterior.

park.name: Arches National Park
park.description: Visit Arches to discover a landscape of contrasting colors, land forms, and textures unlike any other in the world. The park has over 2,000 natural stone arches and hundreds of soaring pinnacles, massive rock fins, and giant balanced rocks. This red-rock wonderland will amaze you with its formations, refresh you with its trails, and inspire you with its sunsets.

images.title: The Organ with Potholes
images.altText: a stone monolith reflected in standing water
images.caption: The Organ rock formation is reflected in one of many natural potholes.

images.title: Double O Arch
images.altText: a broad, red arch with rock pinnacles in the background
images.caption: Double O Arch is one of many large arches in the Devils Garden area

images.title: Delicate Arch
images.altText: a stone arch
images.caption: Delicate Arch is perhaps the most famous natural arch in the world.

images.title: Milky Way over the Garden of Eden
images.altText: the Milky Way arcs above silhouetted stone pinnacles
images.caption: Arches offers some excellent night sky viewing.

images.title: Park Avenue Trail
images.altText: two hikers descend a broad wash with tall rock walls on either side.
images.caption: The Park Avenue trail is one of many hiking trails at Arches, ranging from easy to strenuous.

eatery.description: With respect to the Tadich Grill in SF and Musso & Frank's in Hollywood, our choice is this legendary spot in Bayview. Anyone who has spent time playing soccer on Silver Ave or driving down Bayshore Blvd or just living around SF knows the Old Clam House's iconic sign and that giant clam sitting on the side of the roof and the fact that it's the oldest restaurant in the same location in SF (again, apologies to Tadich). But more people should know about the incredible clam bake cioppino and the amazing kettle bread that's brought out with hot clam juice and the restaurant's own 'Milwaukee steam beer,' which our SF-based editor swears by.

attraction.name: Elvis Memorial Chapel
attraction.description: You wouldn’t ever think Elvis Presley would have a place in Arizona, but “the King” lives on in Apache Junction. The Elvis Memorial Chapel survived the devastating fires at the former Apacheland Movie Ranch and has since been reconstructed at the Superstition Mountain Museum.

park.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
park.description: Open all day and night year round, the tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, conifer and aspen forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Experience a starry sky on moonless nights, or a surreal walk on the dunes under bright full moonlight.

images.title: View of Dunes and Sangre de Cristo Mountains from Park Entrance
images.altText: View of Dunes and Sangre de Cristo Mountains from Park Entrance
images.caption: The classic view from the Great Sand Dunes main entrance

images.title: Children Floating Medano Creek
images.altText: Children Floating Medano Creek
images.caption: Medano Creek is a popular beach environment at the base of the Great Sand Dunes. It flows seasonally April through June, with peak flow in late May.

images.title: Girls Sand Sledding
images.altText: Girls Sand Sledding
images.caption: Rent specially designed sand sleds to slide on the dry sand.  Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, and other items don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Girl Sandboarding
images.altText: Girl Sandboarding
images.caption: Rent a specially designed sandboard or sand sled. Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, etc. don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Girl Sandboarding Above Castle Creek Picnic Area
images.altText: Girl Sandboarding Above Castle Creek Picnic Area
images.caption: Rent specially designed sandboards or sand sleds. Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, etc. don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Girl in Medano Creek
images.altText: Girl in Medano Creek
images.caption: Medano Creek is a popular seasonal stream that flows around the base of the dunes in late spring/early summer.

images.title: Campsite in Pinyon Flats Campground
images.altText: Campsite in Pinyon Flats Campground
images.caption: Pinyon Flats has 88 individual sites, located in the foothills of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains

images.title: Pinyon Flats Campground
images.altText: Pinyon Flats Campground
images.caption: Pinyon Flats Campground is a National Park Service campground located in Great Sand Dunes National Park.

images.altText: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.caption: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak

images.title: Gold Aspens, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.altText: Gold Aspens, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.caption: Visit in late September/early October to experience aspens at peak above the dunes.

images.title: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.altText: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.caption: Elk are sometimes seen by visitors along the park entrance road or County Lane 6, primarily fall through spring.

images.title: Sandhill Cranes Dancing, Dunes, and Mount Herard
images.altText: Sandhill Cranes Dancing, Dunes, and Mount Herard
images.caption: Sandhill cranes spend part of the spring and fall in the San Luis Valley each year. Look for them in farm fields during daytime, then in wetlands from sunset to sunrise.  In spring, they dance to attract mates.

images.title: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Spectacular alpine lakes are part of the backcountry of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Sand Creek Basin, part of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve, contains lush forests and alpine lakes.

images.title: Girls Hiking in Gold Aspens, Mosca Pass, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Girls Hiking in Gold Aspens, Mosca Pass, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Girls Hiking in Gold Aspens, Mosca Pass, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Boy Next to Mosca Creek, Montville Loop Trail, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Boy Next to Mosca Creek, Montville Loop Trail, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Boy Next to Mosca Creek, Montville Loop Trail, Great Sand Dunes National Park

images.title: Hikers on Dunefield at Sunset
images.altText: Hikers on Dunefield at Sunset
images.caption: Plan to hike the dunes in early morning or evening during summer to avoid 150 F sand temperatures or lightning.

images.title: Sandhill Cranes Flying Over Wetland West of Dunefield
images.altText: Sandhill Cranes Flying Over Wetland West of Dunefield
images.caption: Sandhill cranes spend part of each spring and fall in the San Luis Valley.

images.title: Wetland, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Wetland, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Wetlands west of the dunefield are lush and green in mid-summer.

images.title: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Fall is a pretty time to visit the park, with great colors and generally nice weather.

images.title: Red Osier Dogwood and Aspens in Fall, Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Red Osier Dogwood and Aspens in Fall, Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Red Osier Dogwood and Aspens in Fall, Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park. Hike the Mosca Pass Trail in fall for views like this.

eatery.description: There's a lot of debate as to who invented the hamburger as we know it today, but that debate kind of ends at Louis' Lunch, mainly because it's tired of arguing about it, but also because the Library of Congress declared it so. The tiny joint still uses its original cast-iron grills, which cook the hand-ground patties vertically by blasting them with fire. Want ketchup and mustard? Head to one of the other places that claim to have invented the burger: at Louis', your options are cheese, tomato, and onion on toast. That's the way it's been since it 'invented' the burger back in the day, and that's how it'll always be.

attraction.name: Chicken Wire Minnie Pearl
attraction.description: A local artist from the town of Centerville made various Minnie Pearl statues out of chicken wire. His first, an 8-foot-high chicken wire bust of the Grand Ole Opry and Hee Haw actress, was donated to the town of Centerville once completed.

park.name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
park.description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.

images.title: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.altText: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.caption: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point

images.title: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.altText: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.caption: Black Canyon near Painted Wall

eatery.description: DC is the country's seat of power -- I know this because I've seen one and a half seasons of House of Cards -- and Occidental is where the power goes out for a rib-eye or scallops. And it's been this way since the beginning, with everyone from Amelia Earhart to multiple presidents dining here. While the original was demolished in the '70s, it deserves a spot on this list because it reopened in the '80s super close to its original location and with its rep intact, as both of the presidents named Bush have since partaken of its steakhouse fare.

attraction.name: Cabazon Dinosaurs
attraction.description: In the middle of nowhere, California, stand the Cabazon Dinosaurs. There are two dinosaurs, and they are glorious — not to mention highly photographed by tourists on their way to vacation in Palm Springs. These dinosaurs are also known for their appearance in Pee Wee’s Big Adventure. The long-necked dinosaur also houses stairs and a kitschy toy shop inside its body.

park.name: Badlands National Park
park.description: The rugged beauty of the Badlands draws visitors from around the world. These striking geologic deposits contain one of the world’s richest fossil beds. Ancient horses and rhinos once roamed here. The park’s 244,000 acres protect an expanse of mixed-grass prairie where bison, bighorn sheep, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets live today.

images.title: Badlands Storm
images.altText: Layered badlands formations behind fields of green grass under cloudy and billowing clouds.
images.caption: Summer storms are frequently violent and unpredictable.

images.title: Badlands Yellow Mounds
images.altText: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.
images.caption: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.

images.title: Badlands Rugged Peaks
images.altText: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.
images.caption: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.

images.title: Clover Landscape
images.altText: Jagged badlands buttes extended in horizon amid yellow flowers under a blue sky.
images.caption: The park has seasonal changes in colors so plan ahead!

images.title: Badlands in the Winter
images.altText: road leading between snow covered badlands formations
images.caption: Winter in Badlands National Park often creates snow covered wonderlands throughout the park.

eatery.description: DC is the country's seat of power -- I know this because I've seen one and a half seasons of House of Cards -- and Occidental is where the power goes out for a rib-eye or scallops. And it's been this way since the beginning, with everyone from Amelia Earhart to multiple presidents dining here. While the original was demolished in the '70s, it deserves a spot on this list because it reopened in the '80s super close to its original location and with its rep intact, as both of the presidents named Bush have since partaken of its steakhouse fare.

attraction.name: Elvis Memorial Chapel
attraction.description: You wouldn’t ever think Elvis Presley would have a place in Arizona, but “the King” lives on in Apache Junction. The Elvis Memorial Chapel survived the devastating fires at the former Apacheland Movie Ranch and has since been reconstructed at the Superstition Mountain Museum.

park.name: Biscayne National Park
park.description: Within sight of downtown Miami, yet worlds away, Biscayne protects a rare combination of aquamarine waters, emerald islands, and fish-bejeweled coral reefs. Here too is evidence of 10,000 years of human history, from pirates and shipwrecks to pineapple farmers and presidents. Outdoors enthusiasts can boat, snorkel, camp, watch wildlife…or simply relax in a rocking chair gazing out over the bay.

images.title: Boca Chita Key
images.altText: Downtown Miami in background.
images.caption: Boca Chita Key is the park's most popular island destination.

images.title: Coral Reef
images.altText: The coral reefs are located mostly on the Eastern side of the park.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park is 95% water.

images.title: Green sea turtle
images.altText: Green sea turtle
images.caption: Loggerhead, Green and Hawksbill turtles are all commonly observed in park waters.

images.title: Totten Key
images.altText: Aerial view of Totten Key.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park includes the northernmost Florida Keys.

images.title: Snorkeling
images.altText: snorkeling is an easy-to-learn skill
images.caption: Experience the park's shallow reefs up close and personal by snorkeling with some of the park's most colorful wildlife.

eatery.description: Since Florida is home to many, many elderly people, it's fairly surprising we were able to find a restaurant older than most of them. While Joe's has opened up outposts across the country, the original has remained popular in Miami Beach since way back when. The only thing more famous than the iconic stone crabs are the people who've dined there: according to a book written about the restaurant, they include the likes of 'Sinatra, Ali, and Jennifer Lopez.' It's true, one of the judges from the 11th season of American Idol has eaten here!

attraction.name: Cabazon Dinosaurs
attraction.description: In the middle of nowhere, California, stand the Cabazon Dinosaurs. There are two dinosaurs, and they are glorious — not to mention highly photographed by tourists on their way to vacation in Palm Springs. eatery.description: DC is the country's seat of power -- I know this because I've seen one and a half seasons of House of Cards -- and Occidental is where the power goes out for a rib-eye or scallops. And it's been this way since the beginning, with everyone from Amelia Earhart to multiple presidents dining here. While the original was demolished in the '70s, it deserves a spot on this list because it reopened in the '80s super close to its original location and with its rep intact, as both of the presidents named Bush have since partaken of its steakhouse fare.

attraction.name: Avery’s Beverages
attraction.description: This tiny soda factory is also the oldest bottling plant in New England and has been around for almost 100 years. Tours of Avery’s Beverages are highly coveted, as visitors get to make three bottles of their own soda! Be sure to call in advance before your tour to make sure they are bottling the day you go.

park.name: Saguaro National Park
park.description: Tucson, Arizona is home to the nation's largest cacti. The giant saguaro is the universal symbol of the American west. These majestic plants, found only in a small portion of the United States, are protected by Saguaro National Park, to the east and west of the modern city of Tucson. Here you have a chance to see these enormous cacti, silhouetted by the beauty of a magnificent desert sunset.

images.title: Saguaro Flowers
images.altText: Saguaro flowers
images.caption: The flowering season in Saguaro National Park attracts visitors from all over the world.

images.title: Flowering Fishhook Pincushion Cactus
images.altText: A flowering fishhook pincushion cactus
images.caption: Wildflower season at Saguaro National Park is at it's peak in the month of MArch. The Pincushion cactus, however, blooms April through August.

images.title: Coyote Pups
images.altText: Two coyote pups captured on a wilderness camera
images.caption: Saguaro National Park has a vast variety of wildlife, and with the help of wilderness cameras, can be photographed to help with studies and for visitors to learn about animals only seen by chance.

images.title: Saguaro National Park Lighting Storm
images.altText: Lightning strike captured on camera with saguaros in the background
images.caption: Saguaro deaths are usually attributed to natural weather conditions and other natural phenomena. Specifically, lightning strikes have been known to strike saguaros due to the large amount of water stored within their fleshy tissue.

images.title: Weather at Saguaro National Park
images.altText: Rare Sight of snow in Saguaro National Park East Visitor Center (Rincon Mountain District)
images.caption: Saguaro National Park summers can be extremely hot with temperatures exceeding 105 degrees F, lows averaging 72 degrees F.  Winters are mild warm days averaging 65 degrees F and cool nights averaging 40 degrees F. Snowfall is extremely rare in the area.

images.title: Group of Regal Horned Lizards
images.altText: A group of Phrynosoma solare, or regal horned lizards.
images.caption: Regal horned lizards are one of many reptiles in the park, who have adapted to living in the harsh desert environment. Information on how different species survive can be found on the park's website, visitor center, or through our many programs offered.

eatery.description: One thing to know about Franks is that 'the garbage plate' is especially popular, even today. If it was the '60s and you were working a manufacturing job way back when Kenosha had those sorts of gigs, it probably tasted even better. Those hardworking guys got off of third shift and tore into that lusty combination of hash browns, grilled peppers, onion, meat, and cheese. Of course it has cheese: it's Wisconsin. The 'half' version of the dish has three eggs in it. Did we mention that it's in Wisconsin? Another fun fact: Franks seats 55 people in a rail car-style building that was made that way because it was easier to ship on the rails, not because it was a former rail car

attraction.name: Avery’s Beverages
attraction.description: This tiny soda factory is also the oldest bottling plant in New England and has been around for almost 100 years. Tours of Avery’s Beverages are highly coveted, as visitors get to make three bottles of their own soda! Be sure to call in advance before your tour to make sure they are bottling the day you go.

park.name: Acadia National Park
park.description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

images.title: Starviewing
images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

eatery.description: Since Florida is home to many, many elderly people, it's fairly surprising we were able to find a restaurant older than most of them. While Joe's has opened up outposts across the country, the original has remained popular in Miami Beach since way back when. The only thing more famous than the iconic stone crabs are the people who've dined there: according to a book written about the restaurant, they include the likes of 'Sinatra, Ali, and Jennifer Lopez.' These dinosaurs are also known for their appearance in Pee Wee’s Big Adventure. The long-necked dinosaur also houses stairs and a kitschy toy shop inside its body.

park.name: North Cascades National Park
park.description: Less than three hours from Seattle, an alpine landscape beckons. Discover communities of life adapted to moisture in the west and recurring fire in the east. Explore jagged peaks crowned by more than 300 glaciers. Listen to cascading waters in forested valleys. Witness a landscape sensitive to the Earth's changing climate. Help steward the ecological heart of the Cascades.

images.title: Stehekin - Looking down Lake Chelan
images.altText: boats on the water with mountains and trees surrounding
images.caption: Stehekin sits at the top of Lake Chelan, welcoming visitors to take a life at a slower pace.

images.title: Camping on Ross Lake
images.altText: Tents set up in a wooded area.
images.caption: Grab your tent, your sleeping bag, and adventurous soul and camp along Ross Lake.

images.title: Pelton Basin from Cascade Pass
images.altText: Trees surround the frame with glacier and mountains in the background
images.caption: Let the wow factor exceed your expectations while hiking Cascade Pass.

images.title: Backpack the North Cascades
images.altText: Person with backpacking and climbing gear hikes on a trail.
images.caption: Explore the trails and backcountry camping and climbing in a landscape over 9,000 feet of vertical relief.

images.title: Jagged Mountain Peaks
images.altText: Jagged mountain peaks give way to glaciers.
images.caption: Explore jagged peaks crowned by more than 300 glaciers as you traverse the landscape.

eatery.description: Skiing and sustainability are two of the Vermontiest things about Vermont, so it's fitting that the state's most iconic restaurant is linked to both of them. For one, it's located in Warren, which skiers and riders know as the home of Sugarbush. And two, it's committed to sustainability, as Common Man sources most of its ingredients from local producers. Plus, it's in a barn. And not just any barn, but a mid-19th-century Vermont barn -- one that originally burned down in 1987.

attraction.name: Wax Last Supper
attraction.description: Fort Worth is home to a life-size wax recreation of da Vinci’s “The Last Supper” that you can walk up to and take a photo of. The statues are complete with real human hair. Think of it as a more religious Madame Tussaud’s.

park.name: Big Bend National Park
park.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.caption: Hiking the Lost Mine Trail affords many amazing views.

The tiny joint still uses its original cast-iron grills, which cook the hand-ground patties vertically by blasting them with fire. Want ketchup and mustard? Head to one of the other places that claim to have invented the burger: at Louis', your options are cheese, tomato, and onion on toast. That's the way it's been since it 'invented' the burger back in the day, and that's how it'll always be.

attraction.name: Avery’s Beverages
attraction.description: This tiny soda factory is also the oldest bottling plant in New England and has been around for almost 100 years. Tours of Avery’s Beverages are highly coveted, as visitors get to make three bottles of their own soda! Be sure to call in advance before your tour to make sure they are bottling the day you go.

park.name: Carlsbad Caverns National Park
park.description: High ancient sea ledges, deep rocky canyons, flowering cactus, and desert wildlife—treasures above the ground in the Chihuahuan Desert. Hidden beneath the surface are more than 119 caves—formed when sulfuric acid dissolved limestone leaving behind caverns of all sizes.

images.title: The Natural Entrance
images.altText: Looking up through the mouth of the cave on the Natural Entrance path.
images.caption: Beautiful view looking back out the Natural Entrance as you descend into the cave.

images.title: Rock of Ages
images.altText: Visitors rest at the formation "Rock of Ages."
images.caption: Part of the Big Room tour, the "Rock of Ages" is a spectacular formation.

images.title: A ranger presents a Bat Flight Program to hundreds of visitors.
images.altText: Visitors gathered in the outdoor amphitheater to experience bat flight.
images.caption: Every summer evening visitors gather in the outdoor amphitheater to watch hundreds of thousands of bats leave on their nightly food forage.

images.title: Longfellow's Bathtub
images.altText: Visitors watch as droplets ripple through a cave pool.
images.caption: A spectacular view from Longfellow's Bathtub, a long cave pool, inside the Big Room.

images.title: The Big Room inside the cavern.
images.altText: "The Chandelier" is spotlighted in this photo taken inside the Big Room.
images.caption: A scenic view of the Big Room, highlighting "the Chandelier" formation clinging to the 250 foot high ceiling.

images.title: Scenic Big Room
images.altText: Gorgeous formations inside the Big Room of the cavern.
images.caption: A grand view of the Big Room, fully decorated with stalagmites and stalactites.

images.title: Life Among Rocks
images.altText: A hedgehog cactus in bloom in a rocky garden.
images.caption: Amid the arid rocky environment, a hedgehog cactus blooms in the spring.

eatery.description: With respect to the Tadich Grill in SF and Musso & Frank's in Hollywood, our choice is this legendary spot in Bayview. Anyone who has spent time playing soccer on Silver Ave or driving down Bayshore Blvd or just living around SF knows the Old Clam House's iconic sign and that giant clam sitting on the side of the roof and the fact that it's the oldest restaurant in the same location in SF (again, apologies to Tadich). But more people should know about the incredible clam bake cioppino and the amazing kettle bread that's brought out with hot clam juice and the restaurant's own 'Milwaukee steam beer,' which our SF-based editor swears by.

attraction.name: Big White Shirt
attraction.description: Andalusia, Alabama, is the white dress-shirt capital of America, and this highly photographed enormous white shirt sign is a reminder of that. According to Roadside America, the tie is changed seasonally.
